title: Notifications Unreliable
text: I use this app for dLink’s water sensors. The other day we had a water leak. Didn’t receive any notifications. Opened the app when I discovered the leak on my own. Sure enough, sensors showed there was a leak, and they were supposed to alert me by alert, text, and email, but nothing was sent. Tried testing my intentionally getting the sensors wet (no other way to test) and still nothing. Also, the sensors periodically just go offline but the app doesn’t alert me to that. And when the sensors do go offline they have to be unplugged to reset, which makes them useless for monitoring in a remote location. All told, water sensors and app are mostly useless. I’ve had better luck with the dLink Lite camera app – it’s slow and clunky but at least it works. The home automation app and sensors are a wast of money.

title: Worst automation app in my home
text:
Other home automation devices, and their apps, give plenty of feedback and testing. This device (water sensor) and its app took 4 valuable hr to install, in contrast to 15 min for the other automation devices/apps. Worst of all, the app tells us no way to test whether the device is working--without dousing it.  Next, took three tries to connect to wifi, even though I connected while 1 meter from router.  Next: app won't run in portrait, and had to spend more valuable time learning that. Your typical homeowner installs automation to save time. This device, and this app, do the opposite. Despite wirecutter opinion.

Hoping to exploit previous knowledge, I got, and connected, a second copy of the same device, in a different location. Same connection woes, both wps and manual. Total time: 1.5 h, mostly because of drastically limited expectations.

title: D-Link is UNRELIABLE!!!
text:
I have 3 plugs, motion sensor, water sensor, siren, 2 cameras. Happy with the devices but the app just stopped working (looks like the server is down for the past 3 days). The new app supports only cameras. Switching to a different brand (unless they find a solution very soon).
Edit:
After deleting the app, restarting the phone and reinstalling the app, it works again. Could be a coincidence. It shouldn’t happen and I still think the app is unreliable.

title: Software problems!
text:
Not easy not simple! Struggled with a long set up and finally success. Next morning I turn on espresso Maker from app so when i finally get downstairs its preheated, everything good so far I make my espresso then use app to turn off. The switch turned off but the app showed it was still on. The switch on the phone app is now unresponsive. 4 hours later after trying everything I can think of or research the app still fails somewhere in the setup process. I decide to create a new account with a different email and bingo both switches are functioning. If they fail again I’m afraid I’m going to run out of email addresses to create another account. 
Engineers and management at D-Link invest more in your software development. I’m getting the feeling I don’t ever want to buy anything made by D-Link. Good luck!

I also have motion sensors to let me know if anyone is on my property that doesn’t belong and now I’m vulnerable because the company can’t figure out how to keep their app running and never gives any notice or warnings about any outages or length of the planned outage!
Get your act together.  This is unacceptable!

title: Useful for simple automation
text:

my old reviews:

The 2.0.1 update crashed on launch repeatedly. I deleted the app, re-downloaded, signed in again, and now it runs.

I connected 2 of the simpler DSP-W110, and talked to them using iOS 6 and iOS 8. WPS installation was flaky, but that's the fault of Apple's Airport Utility. Manual setup worked fine. In both cases, this app walked me through it. On and Off responded in under a second.

title: Worthless junk
text: Someone bought me a switch as a gift. I was going to return it, but it was too late. So I figured I’d try it. It doesn’t work with my automation system at all. I had to repair it, and when I try to set it up (WPS and manual), it tells me “incorrect pin”. It didn’t even prompt me for a pin, and after retrying and putting in the pin, it still does the same thing. On the plus side, it’s easy to disassemble and replace the WiFi module with something like an Arduino.

title: Zero stars at best

I’ve tried manual setup and WPS setup and nothing connects and the lights in the plug never turn the colors the app says they should. “When light turns amber, push Next”.... ah.... it never ever turns amber. Now what... nothing. No options. No troubleshooting. Too bad I have no other home automation options. Oh wait, I have a thousand.

title: Works well, could use some improvements
text:
My 4 outlets are incredibly responsive. They used to take up to 20 seconds to turn on/off with older versions of the app. Now they're instantaneous. I may have to tap it twice one out of six times to get it to turn on or off. I've never had the indicator not match reality. (I.e. App say light is on when it's really off). It knows if the touch doesn't work. 
I particularly like the scheduling feature. I have my lights on timers. 

Firmware updates on the outlets worked fine, as I was on my home wifi network. Be sure you're connected to same network when updating the software. 

Cameras don't work with this app (even though they show up). You have to use mydlink light.

One recommendation: customize push notification options. I turn them off completely because there are too many motion detection events from my cats on the cameras (even though you can't use the cameras with the app). It would be nice to select the devices that would push a notification (like a water leak!) but I can't because the cameras activate all the time.

title: Worked for Me

Once it was up and running the software even did a firmware update on my device.

I do wish the documentation was better, I didn't realize I needed to create rules to send alerts after the device was setup. Good thing I tested it before I just plugged it in and forgot about it.  That could've caused some issues with another user wouldn't know any better.

text:
This is the upgraded app from Dlink and it is marginally better than the first. I have encountered soooo many issues with this app and the Dlink SmartPlug I am amazed that Dlink would attach their name to them.

I set custom schedules based on our lifestyle. Its not hard to set the schedule; however, the app/service constantly loses the settings. The more comlicated the schedule the bigger the pain to restore. 

The other issues are with the SmartPlug device. It kicks on and interferes with my other wifi devices (the connections are dropped). When this happens the app cannot connect to the smartplugs and I have to reboot my network. I have several wifi devices on my network (Roku, Apple TV, Nest, etc) and this problem is a first.

If I had to do it again I would NOT purchase the DLink products.

title: So many missed opportunities
text:
I bought a smart plug to use as a power monitor; it requires this app. After creating a d-link account and configuring the plug to connect to your wifi, the app allows you to turn off and on the plug, create a schedule, monitor power usage, and set up conditions for the plug to turn off and on. You're probably thinking that sounds amazing; I was too. It's not what you think. You can only create six schedules, period, and then choose which of those six your device will use. The schedules aren't even open ended: you choose a start time, end time, and on/off frequency and which days it will do that. It's like someone had a specific idea for the schedule and programmed it to do only that. 

The other features are equally ham-fisted: 
1. Yes, it will monitor power usage, both total and at the moment, but it only updates the current number when you click on the device's name. That is, you have to hit back, then forward again to see the new usage, it does not autoupdate. This adds a delay as it reconnects to the device each time. Totally irritating. 
2. The total energy use is only shown as a percent of the total for that month. There is no option to show a graph over each day or week or arbitrary time interval (like the Health app does, for example). Also no option to compare multiple devices over time. In fact, the power usage shouldn't be under a menu, it should be front and center on top of the plug's title card. I need that more than I need to select a color for my plug's name. 
3. You can set up conditions, yes, provided the conditions are either "turn off when reaching x temperature" or "turn off when reaching y power consumption." There is no support for if-this-then-that or anything remotely useful. The app even demands access to your location data, but there is no way to say "turn on the switch when I come home." Too reminiscent of Henry Ford's "you can get a model T in your favorite color as long as your favorite color is black."

It really feels like D-link said, "I hear home automation is going to be a big thing; let's cash in on that," made a plug, and then hired a programmer to make a perfunctory app. It does the things I want, sort of, but it's uninspired and could be so much more. These guys need an industrial designer who understands home automation. Or, better yet, just open it up completely and allow people to use it how they want. I might possibly not return it to the store, but I'm certainly not jumping up to buy another one.

Update: the plug/app does not seem to save the power management on/off setting. I turn it on, hit "apply" and then go back, click on the device again and it is turned to "off"

title: Not an improvement - entirely missing the potential for this market
text:
I got the link hardware (initially two power plugs) because I love the concept of a software controlled home and I want my home to be one.

At first I used the SmartPlug app and I wrote several reviews of how disappointing that app is - it barely matches the capability of the hardware power plugs - set a time and it goes on and off. I am looking for *software* features, such as adjusting on and off times by the length of the day, and randomizing the on and off times to look more natural. The SmartPlug app was a complete failure as far as I was concerned and I told Dlink so.

Then they abandoned that app and said we users of the smart plugs had to switch to mydlink Home (this app) at the end of November. They promised more features, but again this is a completely disappointing experience. 

The user interface is difficult to navigate, etc., etc., but the main failing in my opinion is the complete lack of advanced features. It would be so easy to have the app adjust on and off times by the season (i.e., by the apparent movement of the sun), or add a randomizing adjustment to the times so that behavior seems more natural. Why are times constrained to only the nearest half hour? I should be able to have the light turn on three minutes before the hour so it looks like I’m coming into the room to watch a TV show. I could detail another 10 features that would be (1) easy to do with software and (2) very desirable in the marketplace (they would drive sales). I’ve offered to do this, but nobody from DLink has taken me up on this.

This could be a great product. But at this point, I’m not going to invest in anymore DLink hardware because the software is so limiting.
